Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Spectroscopic and Computational Studies of Alpha, Beta-Unsaturated Carbonyl Compounds in Triplet Excited States
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Stephen Drucker, Department of Chemistry at the University of Wisconsin - Eau Claire is funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms A (CSDM-A) program for "Spectroscopic and Computational Studies of Alpha, Beta-Unsaturated Carbonyl Compounds in Triplet Excited States." Triplet states (species having two unpaired electrons) play a central role in many reactions that occur in the presence of light. Prof. Drucker and his group are investigating the nature of the triplet states of a series of organic molecules and aree exploring the differences between the triplet states and their singlet (the species that has no unpaired electrons) counterparts. These studies give fundamental insights into light induced chemical reactions. In addition, the experiments provide benchmark spectroscopic information for testing or refining computational treatments of chemical species. In this project, undergraduate group members will conduct in-depth research. Such opportunities add substantial value to the undergraduate education program, and can also foster rich opportunities for advanced study. Ongoing collaborations with investigators at Purdue will enable Prof. Drucker's undergraduates to participate in a range of activities. In turn, graduate students in the collaborating research group will be able to explore faculty careers at undergraduate institutions as they interact with Prof. Drucker and his students from UW-Eau Claire.

The cavity ringdown (CRD) spectra of acrolein and isotopically substituted derivatives under the cooling conditions of a free-jet expansion, using a slit nozzle source are being recorded. These experiments afford high-precision inertial constants that will be used to determine a substitution structure for the T1 state. Experimental geometrical parameters will be compared with predictions of equilibrium geometry from high-level calculations. In a second component of the project, CRD at room temperature or in a planar free-jet expansion is used to characterize the lowest triplet states of monocyclic alpha,beta-unsaturated carbonyl compounds. Studies on cyclic enones, including cyclic lactones, provide information on the relative energies of the triplet (n,pi*) and (pi,pi*) states, the propensity for configuration mixing, and hyperconjugation between these molecules. The ability to reproduce such differences will constitute a stringent test of TDDFT or other computational methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intelluctual Merit

In the broadest terms, the aim of the PI's research program is to improve our understanding of photochemical reaction mechanisms. Photochemical reactions are those initiated by light, such as from the sun. Revealing the reaction mechanisms is a complex problem that is being attacked from many different perspectives within the chemistry community. In the future, it is likely to be computational modeling that provides the most detailed information about photochemical pathways. The PI's research is focused on laboratory experimentation, but it was designed specifically to complement the vigorous ongoing effort of the computational chemists to simulate photochemical events accurately and efficiently.

The work of the research group focuses on electronic excited states of molecules. Electronic excited states are prepared by using an energy source, typically laser light, to pull targeted electrons away from the positively charged atomic nuclei to which they are naturally attracted. The electronic excitation process disrupts the chemical bonding that holds atoms together as a molecule. Electronic excited states are important photochemical intermediates because their chemical bonds are weakened. The electronic excited species are therefore highly susceptible to chemical reactions (for example, bond-breaking) that occur when the molecules collide with each other.

Over the past few decades, the computational chemistry community has made significant progress in characterizing electronic excited states and in simulating their photochemical reactivity. However, the accuracy of excited-state calculations still does not match that available for molecules in their ground states; i.e., prior to the excitation. Our primary research goal is to obtain structural information about the excited states of small molecules via experimental investigation. Computational chemists can then use the data obtained in our laboratory experiments to test their predictions. The comparison between predicted and observed structural properties allows the computational chemists to refine and generalize the mathematical models they use for computations. The optimized models may then be used to gain insight about larger-scale photochemical processes such as those occurring in the atmosphere.

Our main experimental technique is known as laser absorption spectroscopy. In the experiment, a cell is filled with a sample of gaseous molecules. A laser beam, directed into the cell, provides the energy to accomplish electronic excitation, and it simultaneously serves as a tool with which to investigate changes in bonding.  At certain laser wavelengths (colors), molecules may absorb a portion of the light. The measured wavelengths of absorption can be analyzed to characterize the stiffness of the altered bonds as well as the amount of energy required to break them. 

In the present NSF-supported project (Award CHE-1362897), we used laser spectroscopy to investigate four molecules of photochemical interest: 2-cyclohexene-1-one (2CHO), 4H-pyran-4-one (4PN), 2-cyclopenten-1-one (2CPO), and 4-cyclopenten-1,3-dione (4CPD). Structural representations of these molecules are shown in the attached figure. In the project, we recorded electronic absorption spectra of 2CHO and 4PN using a highly sensitive experimental technique known as Cavity Ringdown Spectroscopy (CRDS). This allowed us to characterize specific electronic states of these two molecules that had been elusive in prior experimental investigations. 

We also carried out computational studies of each of the four molecules. We compared the computed excited-state bonding properties with those obained from our current spectroscopic work on 2CHO and 4PN and our prior experimental investigations of 2CPO and 4CPD. We tested an economical and widely used computational technique known as TDDFT as well as a highly resource-intensive method called EOM-EE-CCSD. 

We found that the low-cost TDDFT technique performed surprisingly well, matching the accuracy of EOM-EE-CCSD in predicting many experimental parameters of the four molecules. We also pinpointed certain vulnerabilities of TDDFT that could only have been uncovered via our choice of test molecules. Finally, we identified an unexpected shortcoming of the EOM-EE-CCSD method; i.e., its inability to capture one seemingly straightforward molecular parameter. We traced this particular inaccuracy to a subtle interaction between two electronic excited states that is exceedingly difficult to calculate.

Broader Impacts 

This project has offered educational and training opportunities to undergraduate collaborators at a level that is nearly unprecedented for a comprehensive public university. Undergraduate students recorded and analyzed spectra of the test molecules; they maintained and upgraded our computer code for laser scanning and data acquisition. Students also used high-end computer programs to benchmark computational methods applicable to molecular systems under study. 

The PI has mentored eight undergraduates (five women and three men) under the present award. As of May 2019, six of these students had completed their degrees, and two continue in the PI's group. The educational and training experiences offered to the student collaborators through this project allowed the six alumnae/i to enter ambitious STEM-based career tracks directly after graduation. One of these participants has earned a master's degree in computer science; three others are currently enrolled in Ph.D. programs at top universities, and one anticipates entering a Ph.D program in pharmaceutical sciences in 2020.

Modified by: Stephen Drucker
